text: Yeah personally I randomise everything in sensible ranges even when I think I'm getting it right because you'll always want the data in the future. The time it takes to for this stuff to work through depends on the complexity of the question you're answering and how good an answer you need. If it's a straight A v B type question with a well constructed trial you can get an adequate answer in a thousand markets, if you're tracking something more complex and you want a nice clean graph you might need 10k. Sometimes you'll think you've got a clear answer with a small number of markets but that tends to be illusory and you'll always be doubting your conclusion. Don't tinker too much as you'll confound your data set and your tinkering probably won't increase your profits anyway, set your thing up and leave it alone. Chances are your bets are already optimal for some part of the market, if you can work out what part that is then you can build from that.

text:
<@UEA14GBRR> both time based and conditional cancelations have their place, I wouldn't discount either one.

Conditional cancellations are great in theory but in practice it's hard to get the balance of seeing enough signal for the cancellation without your bet matching. The logic of time based cancellations is simply that you placed your bet based on a signal and after some interval that signal is too distant to be of value, that's totally sound. What's more it's dead easy to implement.

elements.text:
both time based and conditional cancelations have their place, I wouldn't discount either one.

Conditional cancellations are great in theory but in practice it's hard to get the balance of seeing enough signal for the cancellation without your bet matching. The logic of time based cancellations is simply that you placed your bet based on a signal and after some interval that signal is too distant to be of value, that's totally sound. What's more it's dead easy to implement.

text: Just a note on time based cancellations, you don’t have to measure time using clock time. You can measure using “market time” for example based on a volume traded threshold, or number of price updates etc so your clock runs quicker when the market is more active etc

text: Yes, was thinking about using something along those lines with a fixed time as the fallback.

text: Thanks <@UGV299K6H> theoretical ideal vs practical implementation? Yep that seems to characterise my problems in general. <@U01DJ4DBF9R> I like the sound of that, a real world relationship other than the angle the earth has turned through. Although I can see issues with that too from one event to the next so the time-only option is actually becoming more appealing by the minute (or n thought cycles :blush:)
